title: 105_s1268
content: The Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change the composition, operation, and duties of the Board of Directors. Section 2 regarding membership, operation, and duties of the Board is revised. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, who must be legal residents of the service area. The members select a chairman, and to be eligible, individuals must be U.S. citizens with relevant management experience, not employed by the Corporation. The Board of Directors of the Corporation, consisting of 9 members appointed by the President, must not be Corporation employees, have financial interests in related businesses, or be affiliated with a single political party. The President considers recommendations from public officials when appointing Board members. The Board of Directors of the Corporation, consisting of 9 members appointed by the President, must not have financial interests in related businesses or be affiliated with a single political party. Recommendations from public officials are considered for appointments, and members serve 5-year terms with initial appointments varying in length. Qualified members reflecting the diversity and needs of the service area are sought. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President, with varying term lengths. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members can be reappointed for an additional term. Six members are required for a quorum. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President, with varying term lengths. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members can be reappointed for an additional term. Six members constitute a quorum for conducting business. Members of the Board are entitled to receive a stipend of $25,000 per year, plus compensation for their duties and travel expenses. The Board of Directors of the Corporation, appointed by the President, sets goals, policies, and long-range plans for the Corporation. They assist the CEO in achieving these objectives and prepare for industry changes. Members receive a stipend, compensation, and travel expenses. The Board of Directors ensures goals are achieved, approves budgets, establishes compensation plans, approves salaries and benefits, ensures compliance with laws, and creates an audit committee. The audit committee is responsible for reviewing reports from the external auditor and making recommendations to the Board. They also have the authority to create other committees, conduct public hearings on important issues, and establish electricity rate schedules. The Board is responsible for appointing a chief executive officer who must be a US citizen with management experience in large organizations and no financial interest in public-utility corporations. They must meet at least 4 times a year to establish electricity rate schedules. The Board appoints a chief executive officer with no financial interest in public-utility corporations. The CEO serves at the pleasure of the Board and a compensation plan is approved based on industry standards. The compensation plan for employees in public utility corporations considers education, experience, responsibility levels, geographic differences, and recruitment needs. Salaries cannot be established until the plan and survey are submitted to Congress and made public for 30 days. Employees at or below level IV have their salaries and benefits determined by the chief executive officer. The Tennessee Valley Authority sets salaries for employees below level IV of the Executive Schedule, while salaries for positions above level IV require Board approval. Existing board members appointed before the amendment will continue until the end of their term and cannot be reappointed. SEC. 2 of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change the manner of appointment of staff by the Chief Executive Officer with the advice and consent of the Board. SEC. 3 includes conforming amendments. SEC. 3 of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to make changes to the Board of Directors and auditing procedures. The amendments made by this Act take effect on May 18, 1999, with the appointment of 7 additional members to the Board of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
